elements.content: This study examines the formation of previously unreported crystalline phases of N-methoxyethyl-N-methylpyrrolidinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (Pyr12O1TFSI). The melting point of pristine Pyr12O1TFSI, determined by conductivity measurements, is between −20 and −17.5 °C. Formation of this crystalline phase is difficult and only occurs under specific conditions. Pyr12O1TFSI readily forms 1:1 phases with both NaTFSI and Mg(TFSI)2. The results of single crystal structure determinations are presented. The Na+ crystalline phase provides clear evidence that the Pyr12O1 + cation can coordinate some metal ions, but this coordinative interaction does not occur with all metal cations, e.g., Mg2+, and in all states of matter, e.g., Na+-IL solutions. The TFSI– ions are found in two different aggregate solvates in the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 phase and in contact ion pair and aggregate solvates in the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 phase. The Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 crystalline phase gives insight into the local structure of the liquid electrolyte, where it is likely that a maximum of approximately 30% of the total TFSI– can likely be coordinated in a bridging geometry, and the rest are in a bidentate coordination geometry. This ratio is determined from both the crystal structure and the Raman spectroscopy results.

The results of single crystal structure determinations are presented. The Na+ crystalline phase provides clear evidence that the Pyr12O1 + cation can coordinate some metal ions, but this coordinative interaction does not occur with all metal cations, e.g., Mg2+, and in all states of matter, e.g., Na+-IL solutions. The TFSI- ions are found in two different aggregate solvates in the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 phase and in contact ion pair and aggregate solvates in the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 phase. The Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 crystalline phase gives insight into the local structure of the liquid electrolyte, where it is likely that a maximum of approximately 30% of the total TFSI- can likely be coordinated in a bridging geometry, and the rest are in a bidentate coordination geometry. This ratio is determined from both the crystal structure and the Raman spectroscopy results.

elements.content: One of the limiting factors in the current rechargeable battery technologies is the electrolyte. Conventional battery electrolytes are based on organic solvents like ethylene carbonate, but their use leads to significant safety concerns related to thermal runaway and fire. Ionic liquids (ILs) are being investigated as alternatives to conventional organic solvent-based electrolytes for battery technologies based on lithium, sodium, and magnesium battery technologies. ILs have several advantages over conventional electrolytes in terms of their chemical and electrochemical stability and flammability. In addition, IL-based electrolytes tend to have a wide operable temperature window due to their low melting points and low volatility. Generally, the melting point of the IL is lowered by the presence of small amounts of conductive salts such as lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI), but crystalline phases can form. In order to extend the temperature to low temperature, ILs that do not form crystalline phases are particularly desirable.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

One of the limiting factors in the current rechargeable battery technologies is the electrolyte. Conventional battery electrolytes are based on organic solvents like ethylene carbonate, but their use leads to significant safety concerns related to thermal runaway and fire. Ionic liquids (ILs) are being investigated as alternatives to conventional organic solvent-based electrolytes for battery technologies based on lithium, sodium, and magnesium battery technologies. ILs have several advantages over conventional electrolytes in terms of their chemical and electrochemical stability and flammability. In addition, IL-based electrolytes tend to have a wide operable temperature window due to their low melting points and low volatility. Generally, the melting point of the IL is lowered by the presence of small amounts of conductive salts such as lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI), but crystalline phases can form. In order to extend the temperature to low temperature, ILs that do not form crystalline phases are particularly desirable.

elements.content: In ILs it is quite common that the diffusion of the cation is much faster than that of the anion. This situation is exacerbated by the addition of a conductive salt such as LiTFSI, NaTFSI, or Mg(TFSI)2. The anions typically interact with the metal cations, which further increases the difference between the diffusion of the IL cation and anion. The overall result is low transference numbers for the metal cation. In order to improve the transference numbers, new IL cations were designed that contained ether functionalities with the hope that the IL cation may coordinate the metal cations. In the case of N-methoxyethyl-N-methylpyrrolidinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (Pyr12O1TFSI), among others, the introduction of the ether functionality resulted in an IL that did not have a crystalline phase that was detectable by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) or conductivity measurements. The only phase transition detected in binary mixtures of Pyr12O1TFSI and LiTFSI was a glass transition. The reduced tendency to crystallize was attributed to interactions between the oxygen atoms of the ether functional group and the large adjacent imide anion.

elements.content: This work explores the formation of crystalline phases in the ionic liquid Pyr12O1TFSI. Although crystalline phases have not been detected for lithium-based electrolytes containing Pyr12O1TFSI, this IL can crystallize and readily does so in the presence of NaTFSI and Mg(TFSI)2. The ionic coordination and the role of the ionic liquid cation in the formation of these crystalline phases is discussed. In addition, the determination of the melting point of the pristine Pyr12o1TFSI is presented.
elements.clean_text: This work explores the formation of crystalline phases in the ionic liquid Pyr12O1TFSI. Although crystalline phases have not been detected for lithium-based electrolytes containing Pyr12O1TFSI, this IL can crystallize and readily does so in the presence of NaTFSI and Mg(TFSI)2. The ionic coordination and the role of the ionic liquid cation in the formation of these crystalline phases is discussed. In addition, the determination of the melting point of the pristine Pyr12o1TFSI is presented.

elements.content: 2-Bromoethyl methyl ether (>95%, TCI Japan) was distilled at 35 °C and 2 kPa before being used in the IL synthesis. Pyr12O1TFSI was synthesized via a two-step synthesis procedure, direct alkylation of N-methylpyrrolidine (>99%, Fluka) with 2-bromoethyl methyl ether (99%, Acros) followed by anion exchange with LiTFSI in aqueous solution, as previously described. The lithium, sodium, and magnesium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide salts (LiTFSI, 99.9 wt % battery grade, 3M; NaTFSI, 99.5%, Solvionic; Mg(TFSI)2, 99.5%, Solvionic) were dried at 120 °C for 24 h under vacuum. The TFSI salts and the ILs had less than 20 ppm water as measured by Karl Fischer titration. The IL-based electrolytes were prepared by mixing appropriate amounts of the salt and ILs and subsequently stirring until all of the salt was dissolved. The mixtures were then dried under vacuum. All the sample preparation was performed in a dry room (dew point < −50 °C). The crystals were obtained from solutions more dilute (Na: Pyr12O1TFSI0.84NaTFSI0.16 or Pyr12O1TFSI0.88NaTFSI0.12; and Mg: Pyr12O1TFSI0.76[Mg(TFSI)2]0.24) than the final crystalline phase that were stored in a sealed vial at room temperature for several weeks in an evacuated desiccator in a dry room.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods

Materials

2-Bromoethyl methyl ether (>95%, TCI Japan) was distilled at 35 °C and 2 kPa before being used in the IL synthesis. Pyr12O1TFSI was synthesized via a two-step synthesis procedure, direct alkylation of N-methylpyrrolidine (>99%, Fluka) with 2-bromoethyl methyl ether (99%, Acros) followed by anion exchange with LiTFSI in aqueous solution, as previously described. The lithium, sodium, and magnesium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide salts (LiTFSI, 99.9 wt % battery grade, 3M; NaTFSI, 99.5%, Solvionic; Mg(TFSI)2, 99.5%, Solvionic) were dried at 120 °C for 24 h under vacuum. The TFSI salts and the ILs had less than 20 ppm water as measured by Karl Fischer titration. The IL-based electrolytes were prepared by mixing appropriate amounts of the salt and ILs and subsequently stirring until all of the salt was dissolved. The mixtures were then dried under vacuum. All the sample preparation was performed in a dry room (dew point < -50 °C). The crystals were obtained from solutions more dilute (Na: Pyr12O1TFSI0.84NaTFSI0.16 or Pyr12O1TFSI0.88NaTFSI0.12; and Mg: Pyr12O1TFSI0.76[Mg(TFSI)2]0.24) than the final crystalline phase that were stored in a sealed vial at room temperature for several weeks in an evacuated desiccator in a dry room.

elements.content: Intensity data of suitable single crystals of Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI and Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 were collected on Bruker APEX II and D8-Venture diffractometers with monochromated MoK α (0.71073 Å) radiation. Unless stated specifically otherwise, the measurement temperature was −120 °C. The collection method involved ω scans. Data reduction was carried out using the program SAINT+. The crystal structures were solved by Direct Methods using SHELXTL. Non-hydrogen atoms were first refined isotropically followed by anisotropic refinement by full matrix least-squares calculation based on F 2 using SHELXTL. Hydrogen atoms were positioned geometrically and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms. One Pyr12O1 + cation of Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 was disordered over two positions and refined in split positions (0.78:0.22). The structure of Pyr1201TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 was refined in the noncentrosymmetric space group P1. Most of the atoms adopted a pseudocentrosymmetric arrangement, but transformation of the coordinates and refinement of the structure in space group P-1 failed. There were several chain atoms that deviate significantly from the centrosymmetric arrangement, as could easily be recognized from a drawing of the crystal structure (chiral coordination sphere of Mg, nonlinear bridging group S–N–S, 126.4°). The noncentrosymmetric symmetry was finally confirmed by applying the ADDSYMM instruction of the PLATON program system. The Flack x parameter was refined to 0.52(2). However, best results were obtained treating Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 as an inversion twin with two domains (0.52:0.48). The crystal data can be found in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Intensity data of suitable single crystals of Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI and Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 were collected on Bruker APEX II and D8-Venture diffractometers with monochromated MoK α (0.71073 Å) radiation. Unless stated specifically otherwise, the measurement temperature was -120 °C. The collection method involved ω scans. Data reduction was carried out using the program SAINT+. The crystal structures were solved by Direct Methods using SHELXTL. Non-hydrogen atoms were first refined isotropically followed by anisotropic refinement by full matrix least-squares calculation based on F 2 using SHELXTL. Hydrogen atoms were positioned geometrically and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms. One Pyr12O1 + cation of Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 was disordered over two positions and refined in split positions (0.78:0.22). The structure of Pyr1201TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 was refined in the noncentrosymmetric space group P1. Most of the atoms adopted a pseudocentrosymmetric arrangement, but transformation of the coordinates and refinement of the structure in space group P-1 failed. There were several chain atoms that deviate significantly from the centrosymmetric arrangement, as could easily be recognized from a drawing of the crystal structure (chiral coordination sphere of Mg, nonlinear bridging group S-N-S, 126.4°). The noncentrosymmetric symmetry was finally confirmed by applying the ADDSYMM instruction of the PLATON program system. The Flack x parameter was refined to 0.52(2). However, best results were obtained treating Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 as an inversion twin with two domains (0.52:0.48). The crystal data can be found in .

elements.content: The DSC measurements were made on a TA Instruments Q2000 differential scanning calorimeter with liquid N2 cooling at a rate of 5 °C·min–1. The samples were hermetically sealed in aluminum pans in a dry room. The thermal treatment included cycling from −100 to 150 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The endothermic event temperatures are reported as the peak maximums. The Raman measurements were recorded on a RAM II FT-Raman module of a Bruker Vertex70 FT-IR spectrometer with a laser wavelength of 1064 nm and a laser power that was between 100 and 500 mW depending on the sample. The collected spectra are the average of 500–2000 scans at an optical resolution of 2 cm–1. The samples were sealed in glass tubes. Impedance data was collected on a Novocontrol Alpha A impedance spectrometer in the frequency range between 10–2 Hz to 107 Hz. The samples were contained in a sealed sample cell with parallel plate geometry where the electrolytes were sandwiched between stainless steel electrodes. The samples in the cell were cooled to −150 °C and then heated in 10 °C steps. The temperature was maintained within ±0.5 °C. Smaller heating steps were used around the melting point.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization Methods

The DSC measurements were made on a TA Instruments Q2000 differential scanning calorimeter with liquid N2 cooling at a rate of 5 °C⋅min-1. The samples were hermetically sealed in aluminum pans in a dry room. The thermal treatment included cycling from -100 to 150 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The endothermic event temperatures are reported as the peak maximums. The Raman measurements were recorded on a RAM II FT-Raman module of a Bruker Vertex70 FT-IR spectrometer with a laser wavelength of 1064 nm and a laser power that was between 100 and 500 mW depending on the sample. The collected spectra are the average of 500-2000 scans at an optical resolution of 2 cm-1. The samples were sealed in glass tubes. Impedance data was collected on a Novocontrol Alpha A impedance spectrometer in the frequency range between 10-2 Hz to 107 Hz. The samples were contained in a sealed sample cell with parallel plate geometry where the electrolytes were sandwiched between stainless steel electrodes. The samples in the cell were cooled to -150 °C and then heated in 10 °C steps. The temperature was maintained within ±0.5 °C. Smaller heating steps were used around the melting point.

elements.content: Previous studies on Pyr12O1TFSI have indicated that the IL exhibits no evidence of a melting point down to the glass transition at −87 °C on the basis of DSC measurements. However, it is known that sometimes ILs can be very difficult to completely crystallize. Often complex annealing procedures are needed to obtain fully crystalline samples. In addition, it is possible to obtain different thermal results with the same annealing procedure due to the tendency of ILs to form metastable phases. These phases allow ILs to have appreciable conductivities even in the solid state, which is referred to as plastic crystalline behavior. In some cases, even with subambient annealing, a melting point cannot be detected with DSC methods.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystallization of Pristine Pyr12O1TFSI

Previous studies on Pyr12O1TFSI have indicated that the IL exhibits no evidence of a melting point down to the glass transition at -87 °C on the basis of DSC measurements. However, it is known that sometimes ILs can be very difficult to completely crystallize. Often complex annealing procedures are needed to obtain fully crystalline samples. In addition, it is possible to obtain different thermal results with the same annealing procedure due to the tendency of ILs to form metastable phases. These phases allow ILs to have appreciable conductivities even in the solid state, which is referred to as plastic crystalline behavior. In some cases, even with subambient annealing, a melting point cannot be detected with DSC methods.

elements.content: Conductivity measurements can be used to detect phase transitions in hard-to-crystallize samples. When a solid–liquid phase transition occurs, there is usually a sharp increase in the conductivity. This effect can also be seen after a solid–solid phase transition in the case of material exhibiting plastic crystal behavior. In conductivity measurements, the samples can remain at subambient conditions for significantly longer times and can be easily quenched with liquid nitrogen. These low temperature treatments over longer periods can give the samples a sufficient relaxation time to allow crystallization. This type of protocol was successfully used by Triolo et al. to determine the melting point of N-butyl-N-methyl piperidinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide. In the case of Pyr12O1TFSI, even a long relaxation period at −40 °C did not produce a crystalline phase.

In conductivity measurements, the samples can remain at subambient conditions for significantly longer times and can be easily quenched with liquid nitrogen. These low temperature treatments over longer periods can give the samples a sufficient relaxation time to allow crystallization. This type of protocol was successfully used by Triolo et al. to determine the melting point of N-butyl-N-methyl piperidinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide. In the case of Pyr12O1TFSI, even a long relaxation period at -40 °C did not produce a crystalline phase.

elements.content: In this work, a different annealing procedure was employed, which involved cooling the sample to −150 °C and then increasing the temperature in 10 °C steps. The time at each temperature was around 45 min. Using the results obtained with this annealing procedure, three phase transitions can be detected from changes in the conductivity behavior: a glass transition, a cold crystallization and a melting point. The real part of the conductivity is plotted as a function of frequency and temperature in Figure a, with isothermal cross sections shown in Figure b. At temperatures below −90 °C, the plot steeply increases with frequency. In this region, which is below the glass transition, there is no detectable conductivity contribution, which would be evident from the presence of a plateau in the conductivity. The start of a plateau can be seen at −90 °C and is clearly visible at −70 °C.

elements.content: The most noticeable feature of the plot is the valley in the conductivity between approximately −50 and −10 °C. The decrease in the conductivity at −50 °C indicates that there is a cold crystallization occurring between −60 and −50 °C. In the solid state, the conductivity of the sample is very low. Subsequently, the conductivity increases as the crystalline phase is brought to higher temperatures. Finally, the sharp increase in the conductivity between −20 and −10 °C indicates that Pyr12O1TFSI has undergone a solid–liquid phase transition.

elements.content: To confirm these results and to better determine the melting point, the experiment was repeated both with the same temperature protocol and with a protocol involving smaller steps of 2.5 °C to more accurately determine the melting point of the crystalline phase. The results are shown in . The adjusted protocol with the smaller step size shows that the final jump in the conductivity occurs between −20 and −17.5 °C. It is interesting to note that the valley is not as deep in this measurement. It appears that a different metastable phase with a more conductive behavior was formed.

elements.content: Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI forms a 1:1 crystalline phase in a monoclinic system with a P21/n space group. The crystal packing diagram is shown in Figure . The ions form polymeric chains that extend along the b axis. The ionic coordination of the atoms and the TFSI– geometries are shown in Figure . Each sodium ion has a coordination number of six in a slightly distorted octahedron to five oxygen atoms from four different TFSI– ions, one in bidentate coordination, and three in a monodentate geometry, and to one oxygen from the Pyr12O1 + cation ether moiety. Coordination of the Na+ to the IL cation means that the Pyr12O1 + ion is directly incorporated into the ionic chain, rather than being located in the interstices between ion chains or planes as occurs in other crystal structures of ionic liquids containing N-alkyl-N-methylpyrrolidinium cations. All the TFSI– anions are coordinated to more than one Na+ ion, but in two different geometries. For the anion labeled N2, the TFSI– is coordinated in a bidentate geometry via oxygen atoms from different SO2 moieties to a single Na+. In addition, this TFSI– is coordinated to a second Na+ atom via the second oxygen atom from one SO2 group. The fourth oxygen atom remains free. In this way the TFSI– N2 can be described as a chelating ligand with respect to the first Na+ atom, and is a bridging ligand between adjacent Na+ ions. In the anion labeled N3, two oxygen atoms from a single SO2 moiety are coordinated to two different sodium atoms, thus acting as a bridging ligand, while both oxygen atoms on the second SO2 unit remain free.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI

Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI forms a 1:1 crystalline phase in a monoclinic system with a P21/n space group. The crystal packing diagram is shown in Figure . The ions form polymeric chains that extend along the b axis. The ionic coordination of the atoms and the TFSI- geometries are shown in Figure . Each sodium ion has a coordination number of six in a slightly distorted octahedron to five oxygen atoms from four different TFSI- ions, one in bidentate coordination, and three in a monodentate geometry, and to one oxygen from the Pyr12O1 + cation ether moiety. Coordination of the Na+ to the IL cation means that the Pyr12O1 + ion is directly incorporated into the ionic chain, rather than being located in the interstices between ion chains or planes as occurs in other crystal structures of ionic liquids containing N-alkyl-N-methylpyrrolidinium cations. All the TFSI- anions are coordinated to more than one Na+ ion, but in two different geometries. For the anion labeled N2, the TFSI- is coordinated in a bidentate geometry via oxygen atoms from different SO2 moieties to a single Na+. In addition, this TFSI- is coordinated to a second Na+ atom via the second oxygen atom from one SO2 group. The fourth oxygen atom remains free. In this way the TFSI- N2 can be described as a chelating ligand with respect to the first Na+ atom, and is a bridging ligand between adjacent Na+ ions. In the anion labeled N3, two oxygen atoms from a single SO2 moiety are coordinated to two different sodium atoms, thus acting as a bridging ligand, while both oxygen atoms on the second SO2 unit remain free.

elements.content: Single crystal determinations have been made for both NaTFSI and two glyme-NaTFSI systems. In these structures, the sodium ions have a coordination number of seven in a pentagonal bipyramid geometry. In the pentaglyme-NaTFSI structure, the Na+ ions are coordinated to seven oxygen atoms, six from the ether functionality of the pentaglyme chelating ligand, and one from the monodentate TFSI– ligand. Each Na+ ion and its coordinating ligands form isolated groups with no direct coordination to neighboring groups. Tetraglyme-NaTFSI forms polymeric chains, where Na+ and TFSI– alternate along the chain axis. The bridging TFSI– ligands occupy the axial positions around the Na+, while the five ether oxygen atoms of the chelating tetraglyme ligand occupy the five equatorial positions perpendicular to the chain axis. Although the Na+ coordination is also in a pentagonal bipyramid geometry in NaTFSI, the geometry is highly distorted. The Na+ ions are coordinated by six oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom. Each TFSI– ligand is coordinated to five different sodium ions via the four oxygen atoms and the nitrogen. Coordination by the TFSI– nitrogen is quite rare. None of these crystal structures exhibit coordination similar to that in the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 structure. This can be attributed to the different types and number of coordinating groups available. The Na–O distances for both the Pyr12O1 + cation and the TFSI– anions are between 2.31 and 2.35 Å with the exception of one distance in the TFSI– labeled N2 (denoted with an asterisk in Figure ) that is slightly longer (2.44 Å). These bond distances are generally slightly shorter than all of the other crystal NaTFSI-based crystals described above (2.37–2.49 Å). The O–Na–O angles in the octahedron range between 81 and 96°, with the exception of the O–Na–O angle within bidentate TFSI– (N2), where the angle is smaller (73°). All of the TFSI– anions are in a C1 (cis) geometry in the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 structure, as in NaTFSI. This is in contrast to that of the glyme-NaTFSI structures, where the TFSI– are in the C2 (trans) geometry.

elements.content: Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 also forms a 1:1 crystalline phase but in a triclinic crystal system with the space group P1. The packing diagram is shown in Figure , and the ionic coordination and select TFSI– geometries are shown in Figure . In the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 crystalline phase, the Mg2+ and TFSI– ions form chains (Figure c) that are arranged in layers (Figure b) . The Mg2+ is coordinated in an octahedral geometry by six oxygen atoms of four different TFSI– anions, two as chelating ligands and two as bridging ligands. Unlike the Na+-containing crystal, the Pyr12O1 + cations are not directly coordinated to the Mg2+ but instead are located in the interstitial spaces between the layers of Mg2+ and TFSI– ions. The TFSI– anions can be found in two different solvate structures: contact ion pairs where the anion is coordinated to one Mg2+, and aggregate solvates where the TFSI– is coordinated to two Mg2+. The term “solvate structure” refers to the coordination of the TFSI– by a given number of Mg2+ ion(s) and does not imply aggregation of solvent around the Mg2+. In the contact ion pairs, the TFSI– are in a C1 (cis) conformation and are coordinated as chelating ligands in a bidentate geometry to a single Mg2+ via one oxygen atom from each SO2 group. The TFSI– in the aggregate solvates, which are in a C2-like (trans-like) geometry, form bridges between two different Mg2+ cations via oxygen atoms on different SO2 moieties. In both cases, the second oxygen atom on each SO2 group remains uncoordinated.

Crystal Structure of Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 

Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 also forms a 1:1 crystalline phase but in a triclinic crystal system with the space group P1. The packing diagram is shown in Figure , and the ionic coordination and select TFSI- geometries are shown in Figure . In the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 crystalline phase, the Mg2+ and TFSI- ions form chains (Figure c) that are arranged in layers (Figure b) . The Mg2+ is coordinated in an octahedral geometry by six oxygen atoms of four different TFSI- anions, two as chelating ligands and two as bridging ligands. Unlike the Na+-containing crystal, the Pyr12O1 + cations are not directly coordinated to the Mg2+ but instead are located in the interstitial spaces between the layers of Mg2+ and TFSI- ions. The TFSI- anions can be found in two different solvate structures: contact ion pairs where the anion is coordinated to one Mg2+, and aggregate solvates where the TFSI- is coordinated to two Mg2+. The term "solvate structure" refers to the coordination of the TFSI- by a given number of Mg2+ ion(s) and does not imply aggregation of solvent around the Mg2+. In the contact ion pairs, the TFSI- are in a C1 (cis) conformation and are coordinated as chelating ligands in a bidentate geometry to a single Mg2+ via one oxygen atom from each SO2 group. The TFSI- in the aggregate solvates, which are in a C2-like (trans-like) geometry, form bridges between two different Mg2+ cations via oxygen atoms on different SO2 moieties. In both cases, the second oxygen atom on each SO2 group remains uncoordinated.

elements.content: The crystal structure of a salt hydrate, [Mg(H2O)6][TFSI]2·2H2O has been previously reported. This is the only other reported crystal structure containing Mg(TFSI)2 to the best of our knowledge. In the salt hydrate, the TFSI– ligands are completely displaced by water leaving an octahedral Mg2+ ion that is coordinated by the oxygen atoms of six water ligands. The Mg–O distances for both crystals, i.e., when TFSI– and H2O is the coordinating ligand, are between 2.03 and 2.06 Å. It should be noted that the metal–oxygen (TFSI–) distances are longer in the sodium crystals described above than in the magnesium crystals, which can be attributed to the smaller charge of the monovalent sodium and weaker interaction occurring between the TFSI– and Na+. As in the sodium crystal, the octahedral geometry at the Mg2+ ion center in the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 structure is slightly distorted. The O–Mg–O angles between adjacent oxygen atoms are 83–95°, where the smallest angles occur when both oxygen atoms are from the same TFSI– anion that is in a bidentate coordination geometry. These angles are quite different from those occurring in the salt hydrate, where each oxygen atom belongs to a different water ligand and has angles ranging between 88 and 90°.

elements.content: A convenient way to define the TFSI– conformation, aside from the standard C1 (cis) and C2 (trans), is to imagine the anion in a Newman-like projection. In this representation, the SNS atoms would all be the horizontal plane and the CSSC “dihedral” angle could be used to describe the position of the CF3 units. The CSSC “dihedral” angle in the bidentate coordinated TFSI– is essentially 0° and the CF3 units are completely eclipsed. This is not the case in a “free” TFSI– and in the Na+ crystal structure presented above, where the angle between the CF3 units is approximately 34° or 24° and 21°, respectively. The “free” cis TFSI– angles are determined from the two asymmetric TFSI– anions in the crystal structure of piperidinium TFSI, where the anion is not directly coordinated to any ion. These angles are consistent with other structures with cis TFSI–. The bridging TFSI– dihedral angles are also slightly distorted from the C2 anions in the “free” TFSI–. The “free” trans TFSI– angles are determined from the TFSI– anion in the crystal structure of N-butyl-N-methylpyrrolidinium TFSI where the anion is not directly coordinated to any ion. In the “free” anion, the CSSC angle is 161°, and in the Mg crystal structure it is 140°. The distortion of the TFSI– conformers can be attributed to the strong interaction of the TFSI– with the divalent Mg2+ ion.

elements.content: The thermal properties of the two 1:1 crystalline complexes were investigated by DSC (Figure ). The Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 phase has only one thermal event, a melting point of 58 °C. In comparison, the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 crystalline phase exhibits an exothermic peak in the cooling curve and two endothermic peaks in the heating curve. The low temperature peaks, which occur at −88 °C in the heating sweep, can likely be attributed to an order–disorder transition. The crystalline complex then melts at 77 °C. The X-ray single crystal measurements reported here were conducted at −120 °C and thus, the crystal structure determined corresponds to the low temperature phase.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Phase Transitions

The thermal properties of the two 1:1 crystalline complexes were investigated by DSC (Figure ). The Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 phase has only one thermal event, a melting point of 58 °C. In comparison, the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 crystalline phase exhibits an exothermic peak in the cooling curve and two endothermic peaks in the heating curve. The low temperature peaks, which occur at -88 °C in the heating sweep, can likely be attributed to an order-disorder transition. The crystalline complex then melts at 77 °C. The X-ray single crystal measurements reported here were conducted at -120 °C and thus, the crystal structure determined corresponds to the low temperature phase.

elements.content: The crystal structure determination for Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 at temperatures above −88 °C, i.e., above the phase transition, was disordered and did not allow determination of the unit cell parameters. At temperatures around −40 °C, decomposition of the single crystals was observed. Only data sets collected at −120 °C or below gave data of sufficient quality. The crystal structure of the low temperature phase of Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 could only be refined to reasonable R-values by applying the noncentrosymmetric space group P1. However, best results were obtained by treating the data set as an inversion twin with two domains (0.52:0.48).

The crystal structure of the low temperature phase of Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 could only be refined to reasonable R-values by applying the noncentrosymmetric space group P1. However, best results were obtained by treating the data set as an inversion twin with two domains (0.52:0.48).

elements.content: The Raman spectra for both the crystalline complexes are shown in Figure . Typically, one of the more interesting TFSI– spectral regions is that at approximately 720–760 cm–1, where the peak attributed to the anion expansion-contraction mode is located. This mode is very sensitive to the ionic coordination of the TFSI– and therefore can be used to investigate the solvate species. The peak is located at 742 cm–1 in the pure Pyr12O1TFSI ionic liquid and is attributed to anions that are spectroscopically “free”, i.e., not directly coordinated to any metal cations. For the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 complex, the peak associated with the TFSI– expansion-contraction mode is shifted to 744 cm–1. The peak seems to be symmetric and does not appear to result from two independent populations of TFSI–. Therefore, it can be assumed that the two TFSI– in different coordination geometries found in the crystal structure have approximately the same frequency shift and cannot be distinguished in the spectra. A Raman shift of 744 cm–1 in the crystalline complex is slightly lower than that for the complexed TFSI– in the liquid phase of IL-based electrolytes, as shown in Figure and was previously published. A shoulder at 746 cm–1 appears on the high frequency side of the “free” peak, which corresponds to TFSI– coordinated to Na+ in solution.
elements.clean_text:
Vibrational Assignments of the Crystalline Phase Spectra

The Raman spectra for both the crystalline complexes are shown in Figure . Typically, one of the more interesting TFSI- spectral regions is that at approximately 720-760 cm-1, where the peak attributed to the anion expansion-contraction mode is located. This mode is very sensitive to the ionic coordination of the TFSI- and therefore can be used to investigate the solvate species. The peak is located at 742 cm-1 in the pure Pyr12O1TFSI ionic liquid and is attributed to anions that are spectroscopically "free", i.e., not directly coordinated to any metal cations. For the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 complex, the peak associated with the TFSI- expansion-contraction mode is shifted to 744 cm-1. The peak seems to be symmetric and does not appear to result from two independent populations of TFSI-. Therefore, it can be assumed that the two TFSI- in different coordination geometries found in the crystal structure have approximately the same frequency shift and cannot be distinguished in the spectra. A Raman shift of 744 cm-1 in the crystalline complex is slightly lower than that for the complexed TFSI- in the liquid phase of IL-based electrolytes, as shown in Figure  and was previously published. A shoulder at 746 cm-1 appears on the high frequency side of the "free" peak, which corresponds to TFSI- coordinated to Na+ in solution.

elements.content: In comparison to the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 complex, two clear populations of TFSI– can be distinguished in the spectrum of the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 complex: one at 747 cm–1 and one at 752 cm–1. These two peaks correspond to two TFSI– populations that have been previously assigned to TFSI– in a bridging configuration coordinated to two different Mg2+ atoms and TFSI– in a bidentate geometry interacting with a single TFSI–, respectively. These TFSI– coordination geometries are in good agreement with the structures extracted from the crystal structures and shown in Figure . When comparing the spectra of the pristine IL, the liquid electrolyte and the Mg2+-crystalline phase in panel b of Figure , it can be imagined that the spectrum of the liquid electrolyte can be constructed from the addition of the other two spectra. Following this logic, it can be concluded that the liquid electrolytes are composed of some ratio of the “free” TFSI– as found in the pristine IL and small clusters with the same local structure as is found in the crystalline phase. This is consistent with the idea that the charge-carrying units in the liquid electrolytes are likely composed of a mixture of single Mg2+ complexes and larger clusters with two or more Mg2+ cations.

elements.content: The fit of the TFSI expansion-contraction mode is shown in Figure for the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 crystalline phase. The label “Fraction TFSI–” in the figure refers to the fraction of the integrated peak area, which is proportional to the fraction of TFSI– in a particular coordination geometry. According to the Raman spectrum, the bridging TFSI– accounts for 30% of the TFSI– in the crystalline phase, while the bidentate TFSI– constitute the other 70%. In a previous study on Mg2+-IL electrolyte solutions, it was seen that both populations of TFSI– increased equally with the composition up to 12–16 mol % Mg(TFSI)2. However, at higher concentrations, the fraction of the bridging TFSI– reached a plateau at approximately 30%. The asymmetric unit of the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 crystal structure contains four bidentate and two bridging TFSI– anions, thus accounting for 66 and 33% of the TFSI– anions, respectively. Thus, the results from the Raman measurements of both the liquid mixtures and crystalline phase are in good agreement with the crystalline structure. Additionally, these results imply that the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 crystalline phase provides a quite good picture of the local structure in the Mg2+-IL electrolyte solutions.

elements.content: One of the most striking differences between the Na+ and Mg2+ single-crystal structures is the coordination of the Na+ ion by the Pyr12O1 + cation in the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI structure. This crystal structure is the first direct evidence of coordination between the Pyr12O1 + cation and a metal cation. This interaction has been hypothesized and explored by Raman measurements, but never shown by a crystalline structure. If such an interaction occurs, then a shift in the mode associated with the COC stretching motion around 850 cm–1 is expected as it is known that modes containing contributions of the COC stretching motion of ethers are generally sensitive to coordination of metal ions. In the Raman spectra in Figure a (upper left tile), there is a shift in the peak from 845 cm–1 in the pristine IL to 839 cm–1 in the crystalline phase. However, it is interesting to note that there is no shift of the peak in the electrolyte solution, which implies that the interaction between Pyr12O1 + and Na+ is likely significantly weaker or does not occur in the liquid phase. The same is true in the Mg2+-IL electrolytes. The Raman peak at 845 cm–1 is located at the same position in the single crystal, the liquid electrolyte and the pristine ionic liquid.

elements.content: The peaks in the spectral region at approximately 400 cm–1 are associated with TFSI– anion and metal–oxygen stretching modes. In the spectrum of the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 crystal structure, there are two multifeatured peaks centered at 413 and 440 cm–1. The assignment of these peaks was made using previously published studies and density functional theory (DFT) calculations (for details, see ) on a small complex derived from the crystal structure (). The peak at 413 cm–1, which has a low frequency shoulder tailing out to below 400 cm–1, can be attributed to the SO2 motion of the two different TFSI– conformers, C1 and C2, respectively. Previously, these modes have been attributed specifically to SO2 wagging motion, but animation of the calculated modes (frequencies, intensities, and mode assignments reported in ) favor more of a rocking motion. The features are slightly shifted from the peaks at 398 (C2) cm–1 and 407 (C1) cm–1 in the pristine Pyr12O1TFSI ionic liquid due to interaction with the Mg2+ ion. Therefore, it can be said that these modes are influenced by coordination with Mg2+, but likely do not contain Mg–O stretching motion. In contrast, the peak and shoulder at 440 and 450 cm–1 are likely associated with C1 and C2 conformers, respectively, and can be attributed to mixed modes with contributions from both SO2 rocking and Mg–O stretching motions. Although the modes described here have been attributed mainly to SO2 or SO2 and Mg–O motions, computational results suggest they may contain contributions from CF3 motions. Similar assignments can be made in the same spectral region of the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI crystal spectrum, where there is a single peak at 410 cm–1 associated with SO2 motion of the C1 conformer and a series of low intensity peaks between 425 and 441 cm–1 associated with mixed modes arising from SO2 rocking and Na–O stretching motions. The presence of several peaks can likely be attributed to Na–O coordinative bonds of different lengths, which lead to varying force constants and peak frequencies. As the crystal melts (due to heating from the laser, Figure S3 in the , sample IL:Na 1:1 (s + Δ)), a low frequency shoulder appears at 398 cm–1, which can be attributed to anions in a C2 conformation.

elements.content: In the lower region of the spectrum, between 250 and 370 cm–1, lie a number of bands that have been previously attributed to the C1 and C2 conformers of the TFSI– anion. These two rotamers differ in energy by only 2.3 kJ·mol–1, where the trans conformer has a lower energy. Although many studies have been done to elucidate which peaks are associated with the C1 and C2 conformers, few have dealt specifically with the assignments in the solid state of the pristine ILs, where usually only one of the TFSI– conformers exist. The situation seems to be further complicated by the interactions of the TFSI– with the metal cations in the solid state, which can produce a significant redistribution of the electron density in the anion. As discussed above, the TFSI– expansion and contraction mode is quite sensitive to cation coordination, and thus can suggest whether a significant redistribution of the electron energy occurs. It is also expected that modes attributed to SO2 motion will be more sensitive to cation coordination than modes associated with CF3 motion. The peaks in the region between 250 and 370 cm–1 arise from mixed modes with contributions from both SO2 and CF3 motion and therefore likely have varying sensitivity to metal cation coordination. It could be expected that modes largely attributed to CF3 motion are likely less sensitive to cation coordination than modes attributed primarily to SO2 motion.

The peaks in the region between 250 and 370 cm-1 arise from mixed modes with contributions from both SO2 and CF3 motion and therefore likely have varying sensitivity to metal cation coordination. It could be expected that modes largely attributed to CF3 motion are likely less sensitive to cation coordination than modes attributed primarily to SO2 motion.

elements.content: Herstedt et al. show Raman peaks for tetraethylammonium TFSI (Et4NTFSI), which has TFSI in a C2 conformer in the single crystal, at approximately 342, 318, 297, and 276 cm–1. These peak frequencies were in good agreement with their previously calculated frequencies. Although LiTFSI has also been shown to contain only C2 anion, some of the peak frequencies (shown in Figure S3 in the ) are different from those in Et4NTFSI. In particular, the peak at 297 cm–1 is no longer present, but there is a new peak at 332 cm–1 and the peak at 342 cm–1 in Et4NTFSI has shifted to 347 cm–1 in LiTFSI. It can be surmised these two modes have a higher contribution of SO2 motion and that the shifts are due to the interaction of the Li+ with these moieties.

elements.content: Calculations have also given frequencies for the C1 conformer at 279, 288, 310, 326, 332, and 351 cm–1. If these peak frequencies are compared to those of the peaks in the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI crystal (only C1 TFSI) spectrum, there is reasonably good agreement with four of these frequencies: 290, 311, 331, and 352 cm–1. There is also a shoulder on the low frequency side of the peak at 290 cm–1 that can likely account for the calculated mode at 279 cm–1. Given that the TFSI– expansion contraction mode only shifts to 744 cm–1, from 742 cm–1, it can be concluded that there is no significant electron density redistribution in the TFSI– upon Na+ coordination in this crystal structure. In contrast, there appears to be a more significant electron density redistribution in the case of NaTFSI, also shown in . As with the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI crystal, the NaTFSI crystals contain only the C1 TFSI conformer. The Raman spectrum, which only shows the C1 peak at 410 cm–1, is consistent with the crystal structure. In the low frequency conformation region, several of the peaks are shifted to higher frequencies, e.g., 335 cm–1 with a shoulder at 339 and 357 cm–1, as compared to the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI crystal. The spectral shifts suggest that the electron density has been more perturbed by the Na+ coordination in NaTFSI than in the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI crystal structure. This conclusion is also reflected in the frequencies of the TFSI– expansion and contraction modes, where that of NaTFSI is at 748 cm–1 as compared to 744 cm–1 in the Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI crystal.

elements.content: A similar analysis of the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 Raman spectra can be made, but it is a bit more complicated. In the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 phase, both TFSI– geometries are present: the bidentate anions are C1 conformers and the bridging TFSI– are C2. In addition, there is a strong interaction between TFSI– and Mg2+, albeit stronger in the bidentate C1 TFSI, as indicated by the Raman shifts of the TFSI– in the 720–760 cm–1 region. Between 250 and 360 cm–1, the spectrum of the single crystal is dominated by the peaks at 253, 291, and 329 cm–1, with a weaker peak at 354 cm–1. Both the peaks at 291 and 329 cm–1 have high and low frequency shoulders at 279, 302, 320, and 337 cm–1. The peak at 291 cm–1 can likely be attributed to the C1 TFSI–. The shoulders at 279 and 320 cm–1 can likely be associated with the C2 TFSI–. Assignment of the peak at 329 cm–1 is more difficult, as all of the spectra shown in have a peak at this approximate frequency, regardless of conformation. This band may be attributed primarily to a C1 TFSI mode with some contribution of a C2 mode likely shifted due to interaction with the Mg2+, as was seen in the case of LiTFSI. The peak at 253 cm–1 is a new feature that appears in both the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 single crystals and the Mg2+-IL electrolyte (Figure ). This peak is not present in the pristine IL, which suggests that this mode has a very low intensity in “free” TFSI–. Given that the peak intensity in the single crystal is of the same order as the other TFSI– modes in this region of the spectrum and much more intense than the ν(Mg–O) mode, it can be concluded that this mode is associated with a TFSI– mode that is perturbed by interaction with the Mg2+, which results in an increased mode intensity. DFT calculations suggest that this mode results primarily from δ(SNS) motion of the bidentate TFSI–.

elements.content: The operable temperature window is an important parameter in the development of new electrolytes for battery systems and is determined at the lower limit by the melting point of the electrolyte. This work examines the formation of crystalline phases in Pyr12O1TFSI. The melting point of the pristine IL has been determined to be between −20 °C and −17.5 °C by conductivity measurements. However, it is important to point out that the formation of a pure Pyr12O1TFSI is very difficult and only occurs under specific conditions, which include longer relaxation times at temperatures below and above the glass transition temperature. It is also interesting to note that likely two different crystalline phases exist, as indicated by the different conductivity behaviors in separate measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The operable temperature window is an important parameter in the development of new electrolytes for battery systems and is determined at the lower limit by the melting point of the electrolyte. This work examines the formation of crystalline phases in Pyr12O1TFSI. The melting point of the pristine IL has been determined to be between -20 °C and -17.5 °C by conductivity measurements. However, it is important to point out that the formation of a pure Pyr12O1TFSI is very difficult and only occurs under specific conditions, which include longer relaxation times at temperatures below and above the glass transition temperature. It is also interesting to note that likely two different crystalline phases exist, as indicated by the different conductivity behaviors in separate measurements.

elements.content: Despite the difficulty of forming crystalline Pyr12O1TFSI, the IL readily crystallizes to form 1:1 single crystals upon standing at room temperature with both NaTFSI and Mg(TFSI)2. Although in both the Na+ and Mg2+ single-crystal structures the ions are organized into polymeric chain complexes, the ionic coordination is quite different. The Na+ crystalline phase provides clear evidence that the Pyr12O1 + cation can coordinate metal ions, but it does not occur with all metal cations and in all states of matter. It can be hypothesized that the interaction of the Pyr12O1 + cation does not occur in the liquid phase even with Na+ because the interaction between the metal cations and TFSI– is much stronger than that between Pyr12O1 + and the metal cations. Unlike the crystalline phase, there is an excess of available TFSI– in the liquid solution to coordinate the metal cation, which is preferential to an interaction between Pyr12O1 + and the metal cation. Finally, the Mg(TFSI)2 crystalline phase gives insight into the local structure of the liquid electrolyte. There is particularly good agreement between the crystal asymmetric unit and the ratios of the TFSI– in each coordination geometry in both the liquid and solid state determined from the Raman results. These results suggest that a maximum of 33% of the total TFSI– can be coordinated in a bridging geometry, and the rest are in bidentate coordination geometry. Therefore, it can be imagined that in a solution with excess TFSI–, the Mg2+ will be found in a mixture of single Mg2+ complexes with both bidentate and monodentate TFSI– (where the monodentate TFSI– are available to form a bridge with an adjacent Mg2+ cluster) and larger clusters with two or more Mg2+ cations.

cln_elements.content: The thermal properties of the two 1:1 crystalline complexes were investigated by DSC (Figure ). The Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 phase has only one thermal event, a melting point of 58 °C. In comparison, the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 crystalline phase exhibits an exothermic peak in the cooling curve and two endothermic peaks in the heating curve. The low temperature peaks, which occur at −88 °C in the heating sweep, can likely be attributed to an order–disorder transition. The crystalline complex then melts at 77 °C. The X-ray single crystal measurements reported here were conducted at −120 °C and thus, the crystal structure determined corresponds to the low temperature phase.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Phase Transitions

The thermal properties of the two 1:1 crystalline complexes were investigated by DSC (Figure ). The Pyr12O1TFSI:NaTFSI 1:1 phase has only one thermal event, a melting point of 58 °C. In comparison, the Pyr12O1TFSI:Mg(TFSI)2 1:1 crystalline phase exhibits an exothermic peak in the cooling curve and two endothermic peaks in the heating curve. The low temperature peaks, which occur at -88 °C in the heating sweep, can likely be attributed to an order-disorder transition. The crystalline complex then melts at 77 °C. The X-ray single crystal measurements reported here were conducted at -120 °C and thus, the crystal structure determined corresponds to the low temperature phase.
